text: Subtitle: Amazonia 1960. A Ceremonial House in the upper reaches of the Amazon bas "ceremonial house" being a euphemism for a raised platfor covered by a thatched roof. In the distance, the sun slan low over an unending expanse of verdant jungle. A half dozen HIPPIE EXPATS sit around a low rough hewn ta Atop the table of Heaven an earthen bowl, decorated with  multi-colored scenes and fantastic creatures, is circled drinking cups. ETHAN RANKIN, 20, and VINCE GARWOOD, 19, the two American expats, wear jeans, sandals, T-shirts and long hair. Thei skin has a dull bluish color, the result of residue of a  purification bath. Trance music, constant, evolving, ripp below the surface. The expats look one to the other as the SHAMAN, an elderl mestivo, ladles a brownish brew from the bowl into the  individual cups. His assistant, DON MACITA, 36, helps him Ethan and Vince's expressions fluctuate from nervous to  expectant. Each cradles his cup in his hands as the Shaman, dispensi the "tea," starts to sing an ancient icaros, a ritual cha the melody which will accompany them on their journey. On a pre-arranged signal, each of the ceremonialists drin the brew in one sustained swallow. TIMECUT. NIGHT: the hippie expats are scattered to the fa reaches of the Ceremonial House, each barfing and shittin (off camera, hopefully) their insides out. Vince, wobbly, crawls to where Ethan lies:
Ethan... (no answer) Rankin?
Vince?
How are you?
You?
Weak, spacey.
Ethan's countenance changes: his face becomes placid, his eyes widen.
Ethan?
Oh, Jesus, oh my God...

INSIDE ETHAN'S MIND'S EYE: he shoots at sling-shot speed  across the jungle canopy, trailing stars and clouds to hi right and left; then, rapidly approaching from the horizo a giant iridescent speckled SERPENT zooms into view, its  jaws open. Inside we fly, whirling through the serpent like passenge on an animistic roller coaster, until, twisting and turni the light grows bright and bursts into a kaleidoscope of  color -- Subtitle: Mexico City, 2001.

The rainbow of colored light comes from dozens of flashin bulbs reflecting off a disco ball. Trance music cross- dissolves into techno with a Latin beat. Below, a throbbing mass of kids gyrate and thrash. Amid the mass of sweating ecstatic Mexicanos, RUSSELL RAN 26, hops from one partner to the next. Russ' unkempt hair and club clothes can't disguise what he is: American,  intellectual, middle class -- a student on permanent fore leave. The music grows discordant, off. Russell looks around:  something seems wrong. He stops dancing, stares, anxious. Definitely wrong. He's growing paranoid. Is it the drugs? No, is it the mus an earthquake? No. He pushes his way toward the "Salida." A FRIEND, noticing the expression of Russ' face, calls to him:
Russ, where you going?
I've got to go! Something's wrong!
Where?
I don't know.
Chill, come on, we'll go someplace.
No, I've got to go home.
Home?
Russ elbows his way outside.
Russ, in a panic, throws clothes into a duffel bag in his hostel like residence. The walls are decorated with third world agit-prop,  psychedelic posters and Pre-Raphaelite prints.
Just a few stranded travelers; otherwise, empty rows of  geometric chairs. Russ leans over the counter of the only airline still open:
I need to get to Portland, Oregon,  US, on the next flight possible, the  next connection.
There wouldn't be anything until  morning. Six o'clock.
Put me on it. I have cash.
Russell pulls all the money he has out of his pocket.
(suspicious) Do you have a passport?
(pulls it out) Right here. (explaining) Family emergency.

Subtitle: Portland. An institutionally plain classroom. HUME (HUGH) RANKIN, 3 stands before a mixed audience: male, female, older, youn mostly white. Rankin, angular, clean cut, wears a white shirt with a si tie. If he and his brother Russell could be put in boxes, would be "straight," and Russ would be "hip," although, i fact, neither can be so simply defined. In the back sits Vince Garwood, now 60, wearing professor jacket and tie. It's not a class per se, as indicated by the fact that so listeners drink coffee, some are dressed in soiled work  clothes, others business outfits. Hume speaks:

...I've been through this with each  of you individually, but now,  collectively, we have the joint  opportunity to air any concerns or  anxieties. This DMT --  dimethyltryptamine -- trial is the  first such study to be approved by  the FDA, so forgive us if we err on  the side of caution. We have chosen  DMT as the pioneer psychotropic  compound for several reasons: it  naturally occurs in the body, evident  in such states as schizophrenia and  manic depression. To the extent that  we can understand why Serotonin is  affected by DMT, we might unlock  some of the mysteries for such  disabling disorders. Second, it is  an intense drug. The visions will be  strong. Third, it's short acting.  It's in and out fast. Should anyone  have an unpleasant experience, at  least it will be over quickly. All  of you have previous experiences  with psychedelic drugs, some extensive  experience. This will be a much more  controlled environment. 1.0 mg/kg of  dimethyltryptamine will be injected  intramuscularly, not smoked as is  the usual practice. This retards the  speed at which the drug becomes  effective, but it's the only way to  be sure everyone receives the same  dosage. You've all signed the informed  consent forms, but I wanted to take  this opportunity to invite your  friends and relatives to an open  forum. If anyone has any questions,  please ask. If anyone has second  thoughts about being a trial subject,  you may withdraw your consent at any  time. Questions?
An awkward seat-shifting. No one wants to appear unhip. T GIRLFRIEND of one of the trial participants half-raises h hand.
Yes?
Dr. Rankin...
Hugh.
Have you taken  dimetheltrimethitripo... (awkward communal  laugh) ...DMT?

Since 1970 dimethyltryptamine, along  with virtually every other  hallucinogen, has been a Schedule I  drug, meaning that any unauthorized  use is a crime. I do not break the  law. But yes, I have taken DMT,  inhaled and intramuscular, outside  the country and in legally approved  situations. Is it dangerous? Only if  you fear death by astonishment. (scattered laughter) Because you will be astonished. I  have zero qualms about administering  or using this substance.
An OLDER MAN raises his hand:
There are those, and I'm not one of  them, who say this program is just  an excuse for recreational drug use.
Nervous laughter. The audience is predominantly and  unabashedly pro-drug.

I don't like the word "recreational."  It implies something trivial. Vision- inducing plants are functional, and  have been for hundreds, maybe  thousands of years. They teach us  about ourselves. A DMT voyage, like  any trip, is instructional. You will  return knowing more about the world  around you and the world inside you. (beat) The purpose of the trial is not  recreational, it is scientific.
Hume and Vince Garwood walk along the hallway leading fro the classroom. Participants small talk in the background.
What do you think?
You mean were there any "spies,"  members of Fifth Estate? No, it was  cool. You did good.
Thanks, Vince.

It's such a delicate balance. You  want to be open and candid -- we  have nothing to hide; on the other  hand, we all know the devastating  effects too much publicity have had  on this type of research. (beat) I particularly liked the line about  not breaking the law.

Hume chuckles as Garwood stops at his office, opens the d Inside it's a rat's nest of books, papers and ethographic souvenirs. Framed pictures of Emmanuel Swedenborg, Willia Blake and Aldous Huxley hang between the windows.
When do you start?
Monday. You going to be there for  the first trials?
What time?
Ten a.m. At the clinic.
Okay. Again, good work.
They nod goodbye as Garwood closes the door.

Hume drives his green Camry through the leafy South Park  streets surrounding the university. He slows, turns into the driveway of his 20's "California cottage" house. Portland, the Martha Stewart of American  cities, enforces zoning regulations to preserve the quain nature of its older neighborhoods. On the front steps sits Russell Rankin, unshaven, duffel at his side. It takes Hume, getting out of the car, a moment to recogn his brother:
Russ, is that you? Russell?
Russ gets up, sheepishly slouches over to his brother who embraces him.
Jeez, six months without a boo or a  bah, now -- it's great to see you.  What's going on?
I just felt... I wanted to come home.
Well, come in. Meet Allison... (looks around) I guess she's not home yet. Come on  in. You want a beer or a soda or  anything?
Hugh pulls out his house keys as they walk up the steps.
Water. I'm thirsty from the plane.

Russ looks around the room: sofa, mismatched chairs, dini table stacked high with books -- furnishings familiar to  anyone who has spent an extended period in grad school. A Haitian painting depicting a voodoo ceremony hangs in the dining room. One corner of the room has been sectioned off. A wooden B in the Padmasana position sits on a covered pedestal, bef it, a meditation mat and between the mat and Buddha, ince censors and joss sticks. Hume returns from the kitchen bearing a glass of water. R gulps the water, sighs. There's something on his mind.
Okay, brother, com'on, out with it.  What happened?
It's hard to explain.
Are you in trouble?

No. I was in a club the other night,  well, last night, in Mexico City,  that's where I've been living, getting  into Indian culture and all that and  I got this feeling, this very strong  feeling, that something was wrong.  That someone was in danger --
You had a panic attack.
I had a premonition. (beat) Is Mom all right?
You should have called.
I wanted to see her. Is she all right?
You all right?
Russ nods. Hugh sighs, confirms his brother's fears:
There may be a reoccurrence of the  cancer. In her lungs.
Russell emits a noise; he knew it:
Let's go see her.
I'll call. We'll drop by tomorrow.
We could go now.
(firm) Tomorrow afternoon. I've got to have  some time to prepare her. You two  didn't exactly leave on the best of  terms. (beat) You need some rest. And a shave.

Freshly cut flowers in a vase; the boys' gift to their mo EVANGELINE RANKIN, 59, Russell and Hume's mother, cradles cup of coffee. The decor is middle-brow, but not cheesy ( chest, prints by local artists, etc.). Evangeline, a bit gaunt, exhibits the healthy glow associ with the Northwest's outdoor culture. She wears a shiny g cross. Hume and Russell, also holding cups of coffee, sit on the edges of their matching upholstered chairs. The mood is m formal than one would expect of a family "reunion."
More coffee?
No, Mom, I'm fine.
Me too.
It's from Kona. (off their reactions) The coffee.
Delicious.
Were you out this morning, power- walking?
Yes, with Judy, but these days it's  more walk than power. In fact, we  turned back after fifteen minutes.
Awkward beat: no one wants to bring up her failing medica condition.
(to Russell) Are you planning to stay long?
A couple of days at least. We'll see  what happens. It's good to see you.
Hume sets his coffee down, gets up:
I gotta go see a man about a dog.
He heads for the bathroom. Evangeline and Russ smile; thi is an old family expression.
(to Russ) You were in Mexico City? (he nods) The American University?
Well, it isn't a school in the formal  sense. It's a group of young scholars  with sympathetic interests --
Like a commune?
We wouldn't use that term.
And these sympathetic interests,  what are they?
Indigenous American cultures. Pre- Columbian societies. Tribal  organizations, tribal rites --
You mean peyote. You're talking about  peyote, right? (no reply) Oh my God.
It's nothing to be ashamed of. What  do you think Hume does at the  University, at the clinic?
Her reply is sharp, censorious -- and full of denial:
He's a bio-chemist.
He does drug research.
He has a Ph.D.
Russ rolls his eyes. Her tone turns angry:
Everything that has gone wrong with  this family can be traced directly  back to drugs.
Mom, stop. Just stop.
Drugs have been the death of this  family.
Russ, already on tender hooks, reaches the end of his pro behavior:
No wonder Dad left you. Jesus Christ.  Tell me, has he ever been in touch  with you in, what, twenty years?
She starts to cry. Hume, returning, overhearing Russ'  conversation, groans: he should have never left them alon Evangeline turns to Hume:
He hasn't changed. He's always looking  for trouble, he goes to jail --
Mom, it was petty larceny --
And drugs.
He was never in jail. He was on  probation.
Every time I see him I see his father.
Russ, fed up, stands up:
That's it. (to mother) I don't blame him.
Hume grabs his brother by the arm and, shooting his mothe hard look, escorts Russ to the front door.
(to Hume) She lives in worst case scenario- land.
(looking back) Mom, I'll call you.
They emerge from the proper middle-class home. Hume, keep Russell moving, heads toward the Camry.
I don't know why I came back. What  was I thinking? It was a bad idea.
(reproachful) Russ.
BAM! They run smack into a thirtiesh GARDENER:
Asshole! Why don't you look were the  fuck you're going?
Hume throws an apologetic look at the Gardener ("It's  nothing"), continues toward the car.
Hume, Russ, and ALLISON sit around the empty dinner plate sip tea, wine. Allison, 25, is the model of intelligent  hipness: attractive, long-hair tied in a ponytail, wearin loose plaid shirt.

...I was trying to teach my students  about life. I said to them, "The  only way you can be sure you are  loved for yourself and not for money  or sex, is if you are unattractive  and poor." But then I explained it's  very hard to be loved if you are  like that.
That makes love practically  impossible.
They need to know what they're up  against.
They laugh. Allison turns to Russ:
Hume's talked about you a lot, and I  have to say, I haven't been  disappointed.
(chuckles) Yeah, I really fucked up today.
You should go back, not tomorrow,  but soon, and apologize.
(hard, edgy) That's one point of view.
Yes. Mine.
Allison shakes a cigarette from a pack, lights up. Russ l to Hume; she explains:
Hume doesn't approve of artificially  enhanced nicotine.
One makes certain concessions for  love.
(to Russ) You want one?
Nah. But you know, of course,  marijuana is also carcinogenic.
Well...
Allison starts to stack the plates.
Here, let us help you.
Russ reaches over to assist his brother.
Hume and Russell sit on the front steps sipping Chardonna Night crickets are interrupted by the sound of the occasi passing car.
To be honest, I'd sort of come to  the end of my interest in mescaline.  Mostly just getting stoned.
That's what you were doing in that  club? When you had the panic attack?
(sheepish) Not really.
MDMA.
Yep.
It's an interesting drug. There's  important work being done on Ecstacy  at John Hopkins, in Barcelona:  neuroendocrine effects, vasopressin  secretion...
What are you into?
We're starting a trial on DMT.
The harmalines? Hoo boy. The heavy  stuff. How you get away with that?
Cause I'm a good boy.
How can you put up with it? All the  shit you have to deal with in this  country?

Somebody's got to stay and fight the  good fight. The best labs are here,  the best scientists are here -- you  do work in this country and the  scientific community has to take it  seriously. Besides, with the internet,  everybody is connected now. You know  the organization MAPS? (Russ nods) Through MAPS now we're in constant  contact with research all around the  world: Spain, Finland, Brazil. It's  not like it used to be.
Good old Hume Rankin.
Don't mock me bro.
(lifts glass) Excuse-moi.
(click glasses) Things are going to change. It's too  important not to change.
Psilocybin, that's where I realized  I wanted to be, but I just wasn't...  well, I just I was scared. The big  drugs, the See God drugs, that's  what it's all about.
This extraordinary imagery we all  have within us. These things,  unworldly things, that just appear.  Where do they come from? What are  they trying to say?
The old dilemma. You open those doors  of perception, what happens? Do you  see this world more clearly or do  you come in contact with another  world?
Does the inside come out or does the  Outside come in?
The Freud/Jung dilemma.

It's not politically correct, and  I'll deny I've said this if you repeat  it, but I believe there's a parallel  world of awareness that these plants  give us access to. It may be the way  primitive man first became aware of  the spiritual world.
(joking) "Jesus was a plant."
(responding in kind) I deny it. I never said that.
So, this DMT trial, you got everyone  signed up? (Hume nods) You can't fit one more in?
Why?

You got a bunch of Portland Deadheads  signed up for this trial and you're  going to interview them silly.  Wouldn't it be better to have one  subject who has studied psychotropic  affect, who's personal history is  intimately conjoined with your own,  someone with whom you can truly  discuss the results of the trip?
You want in?
Can you swing it?
(thinks) Yeah. If you don't advertise.
Yes sir. (beat) Tell me one thing, Professor Rankin.
What?
Do you, ah, offer Mileage Plus?
Russell fills out a form under the MANAGER'S watchful eye The Manager can't help but notice Russ' overqualification
We have an Advancement Program.
Not really, I'm between situations.  I need short term employment. I don't  want to be a burden on my friends.
We have an investment in training  you.
(quizzical look) It's a counter position.
This is a service-intensive  occupation.
Mr. Banks, I've worked in the fast  food business. I seek only to be a  diligent employee. I understand  customers.
The local drug paraphernalia, radical press, vinyl oldies Heavy Metal store.
Russ steps over to the counter, approaches an eighteen ye old head in a KORN T-SHIRT.
Chuck around?
Chuck who?
Wistelm. "Chuckie Wisdom."
Oh yeah, Chuckie. No, nah, I don't  know.
I used to hang here.
He got busted -- or maybe not, I'm  not sure. That was before my time.
How long you been here?

Six weeks. (recognizing him) You're Russ Rankin, right? (Russ shrugs) I'm Joe. I came here, like before I  had this, like job -- you're heavy,  you were like a major dope dude huh? (calls to unseen  employee) Hey, this is Russ Rankin.
Russ changes his mind about coming here:
My name's Bob.
A TEENAGE FEMALE EMPLOYEE, tattooed, huge breasted under Marley shirt, walks over.
Yeah?
I was just looking for Chuckie Wisdom.
Chuckie who?
Hey, it's nothing. Groove on.
He walks off.
You find him, tell him I got some  crabs of his.

Russell, with three other trial participants, walks down severe hospital corridor with Hume and two ASSISTANTS. Russ, looking at the patient rooms, the white walls, the  brutal machinery of modern medicine, turns to Hume:
And they wonder why people have bad  trips?
The setting isn't what it should be,  but it's important to operate in a  clinical environment. Anyway, the  "set," the mind set, is more important  than the physical setting.
No problem.

Russ and the other volunteers sit in leisure chairs in a  white-walled room. Each, sleeves rolled up, has a blood  pressure cuff and IV attached to one arm, a double-valve  blood needle to the other. EKG wires extend from under th smocks. The Assistant draws blood from each of the participants a Hume, wearing a blue button down collar shirt with a dark tie, lowers the lights on a rheostat.

We will, during the duration of the  trial, approximately twenty minutes,  draw blood at regular intervals as  well as check pupil diameters --  none of which will effect your  experience. If anything, it will  provide a comforting connection to  the real world of the clinic. Are  there any questions?

No questions. The volunteers are prepared, even eager. Hu steps back to five video cameras, one trained on each of participants, checks if they are running: all red lights  glow. Hume steps away, looks as the door opens: Garwood enters darkened room.
Relax your muscles, let the tension  flow from your bodies and: pay  attention.

Hume gives the signal: the Assistants move from one  participant to the next, opening the IV valves, letting t saline/DMT mix flow into the tubes. The Assistants withdr pick up their clipboards, sit on folding chairs, one agai each wall. EKG machines: heart rates slow. Trance music, first a faint echo, grows louder; the drug  starts to take effect: Russell's eyes slowly close as the camera goes through the eyelid, into his mydriatic (dilat eyeball. Author's Note: There are several extended trip sequences the script. Although I will sketch the rudimentary stages each trip, words are inadequate to describe a multi-layer constantly morphing hallucinogenic experience. Although t trip descriptions necessarily fall into linear, logical  patterns, the final screen images should be much more fre flowing and imagistic. A better reference would be by the computer graphic "trip" videos put out by Sony Music Vide (with titles like "Odyssey Into the Mind's Eye," "Luminou Visions" and "Ancient Alien"). The effects that can be cr by cutting edge computer graphics are, as the saying goes "mind blowing." IN RUSS' MIND'S EYE: the geometric lines of the room coll fall away as we tumble, into the vortex, through the twis tube to the other side.
It's falling away...

The sound of crinkling cellphone, a rising tone, then,  suddenly, out of the tunnel the world explodes in splinte mandalas of pink, red, and orange. It is as Mircea Eliade wrote about the religious experience, "a complete rupture the mundane plain." The kaleidoscope of splintered colors trails like a fleet firebird giving way to an undulating SEA OF SERENITY. Off to the left, in the distance, lies the Ice Country, b we're not going there. A flock of strangely colored birds glide below, their trills merging with the music like a c We pass the waterfall where dead souls bathe. The effect is not unlike that of a child observing a thre ring circus: so much is happening, so much that we've nev seen before, all of it simultaneous -- and all of it so  astonishing. There's no way to absorb it all. One only wa with slack-jawed wonder. IN THE CLINIC: Hume watches as an Assistant takes Russ' b pressure. Russell sits unmoving, lost in time and space. IN HIS MIND'S EYE: a HIGH PLAIN appears in the distance;  approaching, it's green and welcoming. On the horizon, an eerie light glows. Small creatures scramble across the plain as we land. As  they approach we realize these are the ELVES, miniature  mutating folk radiating joy and playfulness. They're all  smiling. The grass grows tall, soon we're in an ancient overgrown  FORREST. The elves lead us through the darkening wood. A panther watches from a tree limb, his eyes piercing tre The music darkens, an ominous mood wells from the Earth's core. But the elves still seem happy and we follow, moving quic now. Out of the forest, on the valley floor, sits the SAUCER, source of the eerie glow. The silver skin pulsates like a living being. This is where the elves have been leading u but now, suddenly they're gone. The door to the saucer opens; a blue warmth radiates from within. A human silhouette appears in the doorway. We dra nearer. The silhouette is Evangeline, her arms across her stomach She pulls back her hands, revealing an open wound. Her ha are red with blood. IN THE CLINIC: Russ shifts in his chair anxiously. It's a if he's trying to get out of his body without standing up Hume checks the EKG monitor; Russ' heart rate increases.
Mom.

IN HIS MIND'S EYE: Evangeline extends her hand, leads us  inside. The music, still hypnotic, has taken on a frighte Nine Inch Nails quality. Inside the saucer we're led from room to room. Shifting p of shades of blue surround us. The floors seem liquid at feet. He hears a TV show, "Jeopardy." Alex Trebek says "T Taj Mahal, Solomon's Palace and Billy Joel's beach house have this in common." Evangeline takes us to where a thirty year-old man stands wearing dark old jeans and a T-shirt. Hanging from one ha is a blood dripping butcher knife. This is the MURDERER. IN THE CLINIC: Russ squirms. Hume checks his watch; it's  been eighteen minutes. One of the other participants open his eyes, says something to one of the Assistants.
Stop, stop.

IN RUSS' MIND'S EYE: The murderer lifts his other hand. F his fingers tangles Evangeline's gold cross. He presses t cross into our palm. We fall into the WHIRLPOOL. IN THE CLINIC: Russell awakens, frightened, trembling, hi face beaded with sweat. Hume kneels beside him. Russ atte to speak, but cannot.
Russ?
He looks at the EKG monitor, double-checks with the Assis who is taking Russ' pulse, checking his pupil dilation. S indicates Russ is fine.
(groggy) We have to go to mother's house.
We can't do that. You're not fully  down yet. We'll go in a while.
(soft, urgent) No, we've got to go now.
Hume attempts to calm him, but now Russ is on his feet,  pulling the EKG sensors from his chest, blood pressure cu from his arm. He starts for the exit.
I'll go on my own.
Russ breaks free from the Assistant's attempt to restrain him, heads for the exit. Hume calls after:
No, no, I'll take you. Let's get  your shirt.
Hume throws a perplexed backward glance to Garwood as he  follows.
Russ, wearing his street shirt, rides shotgun as Hume  negotiates the Camry though a Portland suburban subdivisi Russ' eyes are focused on the road ahead. Classic rock pl on the FM.
Turn it off.
It takes Hume a moment to understand what his brother mea He clicks off the stereo.
What happened? What's this all about? (no reply) You're just going to sit there? I  mean, what can be so bad? You're not  going to create a scene are you?

They turn a corner: the house appears. Russ tenses. Hume pulls into the drive, parks behind their mother's va They get out, walk to the front door. At the door: Hume rings the chimes. No answer. Rings agai The brothers look to each other. Hume turns the knob: it' unlocked. The door swings open. They step inside --

Everything appears normal, everything as it was the day  before. Russ and Hume walk into the living room. Day old cut flowers in their vase. Russell relaxes. Maybe it's nothing after all. Then, from the TV room, he HEARS A SOUND which sends a chill up his  spine: "Jeopardy." Alex Trebek's voice echoes from the den: "The Taj Mahal,  Solomon's Palace and Billy Joel's beach house have this i common." Buzzer sound. "Yes, Mike." Russ turns his head,  catching TV Mike as he replies: "They were all built for  love." Russ, now fearful, notices red stains on the carpet as th proceed. The bedroom door is ajar. It hits Hume: somethin is very wrong:
Mom?

Russell pushes the bedroom door open, revealing a horrifi tableau. Evangeline, her stomach sliced open, her hands cut with  defensive wounds, her breast repeatedly punctured, lies b the bed. Everywhere, the room shows signs of a struggle: lamp knocked over, chair askew, coverlet half off the  mattress. Hume resists the impulse to rush to his mother's side. Ru his head in his hands, sobs.
(quiet) Don't touch anything. It's a crime  scene. Mother, Mom, Mom...
Hume steps closer.
She's dead.
(voice cracks) Yes. (beat) I'm going to another room, call 911.  Are you all right? I mean, to deal  with the police and whatever. I could  drive you home, come back and call.
No, I'm all right. I'm down. Go ahead  and call. (beat) Hume?
Yeah? (no reply) Russell?
I saw it.

Paramedics wheel the gurney carrying Evangeline's body ba to an awaiting EMS vehicle. Police cars are parked at eve which angle. Crime scene tape fences off the front yard a officers hold back curious onlookers and media crew.

Hume and Russ sit on the chairs they occupied the day bef Across from them is Homicide Detective LAWRENCE, 40, a ve of such situations. Police and M.E. technicians go through the house with ord precision, collecting evidence. Glancing time to time at victim's sons, the technicians work as silently as possib
...I'll be in touch tomorrow, Dr.  Rankin, but you touched nothing?
The front door, we walked here, here,  there -- otherwise, nothing. I used  the phone in the den.
We were here yesterday. That's why  we came back. We had an argument.
(explains) We came to see Mom and, well, you  know, the usual parent-child stuff.  We wanted to patch it up.
That's why you were together?
Yes.
And your father?
My father and my mother broke up  twenty... one years ago. She hasn't  seen him since.
Where is he now?
I don't know.
Is there anything, you can think  about it, was there anything unusual,  anything that might give us a  direction to pursue?
Hume shrugs.
She was sick. She had lung cancer.  She had a mastectomy, but the cancer  returned.
How is this relevant?
It isn't. But, I mean, what kind of  person kills a dying woman?

Incense burns at the foot of the shrine. Blue TV light  flickers from a TV across the room. Hume, Russell and Allison, somber, sit watching the video of Russ' trip. Hume holds a stapled EKG of Russ' minute-b minute progress. ON SCREEN: Russell, EKG wires under his smock, IV and cuf on his arm, lies quiescent on the Clinic lounge chair.
(watching the video) The grass grew and it was like a  forest, a jungle, there was a  panther...
